Legal_Issue: Whether the Board's finding that applicants failed to rebut the presumption of state protection was reasonable
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse, alleging inadequate state protection in Saint Lucia
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision was reasonable; claim rejected
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Board's rejection
Court_Ruling: Court dismissed the application for judicial review, upholding the Board's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic abuse and alleged inadequate state protection in Saint Lucia
Legal_Standard: Claimants must prove inadequate state protection with clear evidence; adequacy suffices, not perfection
Assessment_Factor: Evidence of diligence in seeking protection, availability of mechanisms for domestic violence victims
Applicable_Legislation: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of Board's decision
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's findings
Evidence_Used: Alleged police inefficiency in Saint Lucia, available domestic violence protection mechanisms
Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence and lack of effective state protection
Evidence_Assessed: Insufficient evidence of diligence in seeking protection
Governing_Rule: Under sections 96 and 97, claimants must demonstrate inadequate state protection with sufficient evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide clear evidence that state protection was inadequate despite available mechanisms
Outcome: Refugee claim rejected; judicial review dismissed
Harm_Assessment: Risk of harm from domestic violence in Saint Lucia
Cause_Description: Applicants claimed refugee status due to domestic abuse, alleging inadequate state protection in Saint Lucia
Evidence_Handling: Board considered all evidence and found applicants did not meet burden of proof
Evidence_Issues: Lack of sufficient evidence to rebut presumption of state protection
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicants did not demonstrate inadequate state protection despite available remedies
Decision_Rationale: Board reasonably concluded applicants failed to rebut presumption of state protection
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence of efforts to access existing protection mechanisms
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard in judicial review; burden of proof on claimants to show inadequate state protection
